newsitem.title: USA: United CEO sees deal to allow regional jets - paper.
newsitem.headline: United CEO sees deal to allow regional jets - paper.

text.p: United Airlines Chairman Gerald Greenwald predicted a solution will be reached with the Air Line Pilots Association to allow commuter carriers to fly regional jets as part of the United Express System.
In an interview published in Friday editions of the Washington Post, Greenwald said he expected to work out an agreement with the pilots union "sometime soon."

Under the ALPA contract, the union must give permission for a commuter airline to fly the new 50-seat regional jets. So far, the union has insisted that United must own the jets and United pilots, not the commuter line pilots, must fly them.
The union's leadership at United has called a special meeting for late next week to consider the regional jet issue.
United Airlines is a unit of UAL Corp.
